message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation is consistent with breast cancer in males, which is rare but can occur. In males, invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type, not lobular. The presence of axillary nodes suggests malignancy. Breast cancer in males is usually positive for estrogen receptor, so option (B) is true. BRCA analysis may be recommended in his family members to assess their risk. Endocrine therapy, such as tamoxifen, may have a role in treatment depending on the estrogen receptor status of the tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a painless firm mass with nipple retraction, skin fixation, and palpable axillary nodes suggest breast cancer. In males, ductal carcinoma is more common than lobular carcinoma. Breast cancers in males are typically positive for estrogen receptor. BRCA analysis is recommended in his family members. Endocrine therapy may have a role in treating breast cancer.

We refer to Medscape for help. The presentation of a painless firm mass with nipple retraction and fixed skin suggests breast cancer. In males, ductal carcinoma is more common than lobular carcinoma. Breast cancer in males is often positive for estrogen receptor. BRCA analysis may be recommended in the patient and his family members. Endocrine therapy may be used in the treatment of breast cancer in males if the cancer is positive for estrogen receptor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests breast cancer in males, and it is more commonly ductal carcinoma than lobular carcinoma. The presence of axillary nodes suggests metastasis. Breast cancer in males can be positive for estrogen receptors. BRCA analysis may be recommended in his family members, as it can indicate an increased risk of breast and other cancers. Endocrine therapy can have a role in the treatment of male breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with male breast cancer. Lobular cancer is more common in females. Male breast cancers have been found to be positive for estrogen receptor in up to 90% of cases. BRCA analysis should be considered for male patients with breast cancer if there is a family history of breast or ovarian cancer. Endocrine therapy may have a role in treatment, depending on the receptor status of the tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a painless mass with nipple retraction and skin fixation is concerning for breast cancer in males. In males, ductal carcinoma is the most common breast cancer, and these tumors tend to be positive for estrogen receptor. BRCA analysis may be recommended in this patient and his family members, as some male breast cancers may be related to inherited BRCA mutations. Endocrine therapy may have a role in the treatment of male breast cancer, particularly if the tumor is positive for hormone receptors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests breast cancer. In males, invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common breast cancer. Retraction of the nipple and fixed skin suggest a locally advanced stage. Breast cancers can be positive or negative for estrogen receptor, but in this case, it is positive. BRCA analysis is recommended for all first-degree relatives of males with breast cancer. Endocrine therapy plays a role in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation with a painless, firm mass in the breast with nipple retraction and axillary node involvement is suggestive of male breast cancer. Male breast cancer often expresses estrogen receptor positivity, unlike female breast cancer where there is a mix of hormone receptor status. Lobular cancer is rare in men. BRCA analysis is recommended as male breast cancer patients can be carriers of BRCA mutations. Endocrine therapy is a treatment option for hormone receptor-positive male breast cancer. Therefore, only option (B) is true regarding this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description fits the criteria for male breast cancer, which is usually positive for estrogen receptor. Lobular cancer is rare in males, and genetic testing may be recommended for family members. Endocrine therapy may play a role in treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is suggestive of male breast cancer, with nipple retraction and skin fixation being key features. Lobular cancer is less common in males than females, and the condition is usually positive for estrogen receptor. BRCA analysis may be recommended in family members, as there may be a hereditary component to the cancer. Endocrine therapy may be used in the treatment, as male breast cancer can be hormone receptor positive. Therefore, option (B) is the correct statement.
